Metal-support interaction (MSI) plays an important role in heterogeneous catalysis, that could be well regulated by many strategies. Here, Ni@ZrO2 catalysts were controllably synthesized by sacrificial Zr-MOFs template strategy, and were applied to the dry reforming of methane (DRM). Amongst, the Ni/ZrO2-B catalyst shows the best performance toward CH4 and CO2 conversion, H2/CO ratio, and stability, following by Ni/ZrO2-A and Ni/ZrO2 C catalysts. The difference in catalytic performance should be ascribed to different synthetic strategy, resulting in different properties of Ni species and ZrO2 matrix, and interface interaction. It revealed that small Ni particles were benefit for CH4 activation, and strong MSI boosted CO2 activation, that could remain the Ni dispersion and thermal stability. This study is beneficial to the catalyst design in DRM reaction. Graphical abstract A Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs) strategy was proposed to assist the preparation of supported Ni/ZrO2 catalyst. The embedded structure and strong metal-support interaction endow it with superior performance in dry reforming of methane (DRM). Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ni/ZrO2 catalyst Zr-MOFs Metal-support interaction Dry reforming of methane Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In the past decades, dry reforming of methane (DRM) attracts considerable attention, because it can convert two important greenhouse gases (CH4 and CO2) to valuable syngas (CO + H2) [1–3]. The latter can be further applied for energy chemicals through the Fischer−Tropsch process. Taking the energy and environment requirement into account, many efforts have been focused on the DRM study. However, DRM is a thermodynamic endothermic reaction, always occurs under harsh condition. Thus, the relevant issues, such as sintering, carbon deposit and adverse side reactions, severely restrict its industrial application [4]. The development of advanced catalyst system is crucial for resolving these issues. It is well accepted that Ni-based catalysts are considered as the promising catalysts in DRM reaction because of their low cost, abundant reserves and high activity [5–8]. Nevertheless, Ni-based catalysts still inevitably tend to deactivate due to the sintering and coking. In the past decade, many efforts have been devoted on the exploration of highly active Ni based catalysts with good thermal anti-sintering and coking resistance, including the regulation of metallic particle size, Ni particle distribution and metal-support interaction (MSI) [6,7,9]. For example, Ni particles were embedded in (ir)reducible oxides shell forming the core-shell structural catalysts [10–13], that could effectively prevent the high-temperature sintering. The modification of Ni core or shell could also improve coking resistance. Mesoporous supports with large surface area were also employed to disperse the active sites. Besides, rare earth oxides (e.g., CeO2, La2O3) [14,15], perovskite type [16] and defective support [17,18] were also used to strengthen the MSI. It was revealed that the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) could restrict the sintering of nickel particles, and the high Ni dispersion could alleviate the carbon deposit. In fact, the SMSI also remain the high dispersion. Thus, it is necessary to construct/regulate the SMSI and explore the its effect on the performance in DRM reaction. Metal-organic-frameworks (MOFs) derived materials have been attracted extensive attention due to their retained morphology, large surface area and functionality [19]. Recently, metal-oxide interfaces were formed by encapsulating metal nanoparticle with MOFs, yielding strong electronic interaction via MSI after subsequent thermal pyrolysis [20–26]. We have prepared a series of Ag@Co3O4, Pt@Co3O4 and Pd/CeO2 catalysts using Co-MOFs or Ce-MOFs as sacrificial templates [20–22]. Because of the SMSI, partial electrons were transferred from oxides to metal. The formed interfacial catalysts showed good redox ability and abundant surface oxygen species, contributing to superior catalytic oxidation activity. Zhang et al. [23] prepared MOF-derived Pd@ZrO2 catalysts, and the formed SMSI promotes the redox ability and the formation of oxygen vacancies, resulting in good toluene oxidation activity. Thus, it is effective to construct the metal/oxide interface and strengthen the MSI through MOFs-template sacrificial strategy. As we all know, metal/oxide interface catalysts derived from MOFs displayed excellent performance in oxidation reaction. How does it perform in the reduction reaction (e.g., DRM)? This issue is still needed to be explored. Herein, a series of Ni@ZrO2 were prepared by using Zr-MOFs as sacrificial template. On the basis of the tunable synthetic strategy, the interfacial interactions in the different Ni/ZrO2 catalysts were regulated. Various techniques, including XRD, TEM, N2 sorption, TEM, XPS, TG, H2-TPR and in-situ DRIFTS, were employed to characterize ZrO2 phase, Ni particles dispersion, redox property and surface chemical state, further clarifying the MSI. In addition, the CO2 adsorption behavior, catalytic performance and carbon deposit were also be involved in research content. Finally, a structure–activity relationship was well established. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Zr-MOFs was synthesized by modified solvothermal method [24]. Typically, 1,4-benzendicarboxylic acid, zirconium(IV) dinitrate oxide hydrate and concentrated formic acid were dissolved into the N,N-dimethylformamide forming a homogeneous solution, then were transferred into hydrothermal reaction vessel and kept at 120 °C for 24 h. After filtering, washing, and drying, the product was further calcined at 800 °C for 5 h, generating ZrO2 products. For the Ni/ZrO2-A catalyst, a certain amount of Ni(NO3)2 6H2O was introduced into the hydrothermal reaction vessel with Zr source. For the Ni/ZrO2-B catalyst, a certain amount of Ni(NO3)2 6H2O was introduced into Zr-MOFs. For the Ni/ZrO2-C catalyst, a certain amount of Ni(NO3)2 6H2O was introduced into the formed ZrO2 product. The calcination procedure was the same to each other. The entailed synthetic processes were placed in Supplementary Material. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Catalysts were characterized using XRD, N2 sorption, TEM, XPS, ICP-AES, TG, H2-TPR and in-situ DRIFTS. Descriptions for each characterization were placed in Supplementary Material. 2.3 Catalysis activity measurements The reforming reaction was carried out in a fixed-bed quartz microreactor (id = 8 mm) at 750 °C under atmospheric pressure. The reactant gas mixture of CO2 and CH4 (molar ratio = 1:1) was fed at a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 24,000 mL/(g h). The effluent gases from the reactor were analyzed online on a gas chromatograph fitted with a packed column (TDX-01) and a thermal conductivity detector. The high purity Ar was chosen as chromatographic carrier gas. The entailed evaluation process was placed in Supplementary Material. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and morphology As illustrated in Fig. 1 , three different Ni/ZrO2 catalysts were prepared in this work. Generally, the Zr-MOFs (UiO-66) were synthesized by the modified solvothermal method [27]. For Ni/ZrO2-A catalyst, the in-situ adding of nickel source was similar to the synthesis of Ce-Zr-MOFs [28]. In addition, the nickel sources were also introduced into the Zr-MOFs and the formed ZrO2, yielding the corresponding Ni/ZrO2-B and Ni/ZrO2-C catalysts, respectively. Based on this tunable synthetic strategy, three different Ni-based catalysts were prepared, and their structure-activity relationships were further investigated in DRM. Fig. 2 displays the XRD patterns of three different Ni/ZrO2 catalysts. The typical characteristic diffraction peaks of ZrO2 support are obviously observed. Most diffraction peaks of all samples are well attributed to the monoclinic ZrO2 (m-ZrO2) (JCPDS #37–1484). Noticeably, there still exists a few of different reflection peaks at 2θ = 30.3°, 50.7°, 60.3° and 74.6°, that are attributed to the (011), (020), (121) and (220) lattice planes of tetragonal ZrO2 (t-ZrO2) (JCPDS #50–1089), respectively. It can be concluded that the different preparation strategy results in the change of crystallite structure of ZrO2 support. In contrast, the Ni/ZrO2-B catalyst shows the obvious characteristic diffraction peaks of tetragonal ZrO2 phase, following by the Ni/ZrO2-A, but the Ni/ZrO2-C has a little of t-ZrO2 species. This finding is similar to the reported result, that the calcination of Zr-MOFs brought a big effect on the composition of ZrO2 supports, resulting in the mixed crystalline phases [29]. Besides, the peaks at 2θ of 37.4 °, 43.4 °, 63.2 ° and 75.4 °corresponding to the (111), (200), (220) and (311) planes, are attributed to the cubic structure of NiO phase (JCPDS #01–1239). The mean crystalline sizes of NiO were also calculated by the Scherrer equation ( Table 1 ). The average NiO particle sizes are 23.42, 20.47 and 32.02 nm for Ni/ZrO2-A, Ni/ZrO2-B, and Ni/ZrO2-C, respectively. Due to the in-situ encapsulation, it is easily accepted that the Ni/ZrO2-A catalyst has smaller NiO particle size. For Ni/ZrO2-B catalyst, the Ni precursor impregnated in Zr-MOFs also promote the Ni particle dispersion because of the large internal spatial structure of Zr-MOF. After the reducing treatments before reaction, the corresponding Ni particle sizes should follow the same order, and the Ni crystalline size in Ni/ZrO2-B catalyst has the smallest particle size. Previously, the small Ni particle size could provide more active sites for the activation of reaction molecules [13,30]. Thus, it is rationally assumed that the Ni/ZrO2-B catalyst exhibits the best performance due to the abundant active sites. The morphology structure of different Ni/ZrO2 catalysts was detected by TEM technique and displayed in Fig. 3 . Seen from Fig. 3 a, 3d and 3g), there exists distinct change of particle sizes over these three supported catalysts. For Ni/ZrO2-A sample, the in-situ addition of nickel source strategy largely reduces the whole particle size, whereas the increased particle sizes are observed on other two catalysts. It indicates that the Ni2+ and Zr4+ ions are well connected with the linker molecules H2BDC forming the smaller whole particle size. However, the post-synthesis strategy cannot complete the perfect combination between Ni and Zr atoms, leading to the larger whole particle size. Additionally, due to the similar substrate and aggregation state, it is hard to distinguish the NiO and ZrO2 species (Fig. 3 b, 3e and 3h)). Therefore, it is difficult to confirm the related NiO particle size. Through finely comparison, NiO particles appear with irregular edges or corners, while the morphology of ZrO2 particles present with smooth edges. This result can be further demonstrated by HRTEM. For Ni/ZrO2-A catalyst ( Fig. 3 c), two neighboring notable lattice fringes with interplanar spacings of 0.208 and 0.283 nm belong to the (200) plane of NiO phase and (111) plane of m-ZrO2 phase, respectively. For Ni/ZrO2-B catalyst, exposure (111) plane of m-ZrO2 and (112) plane of t-ZrO2 with the lattice fringes of 0.290 and 0.180 nm can be observed in Fig. 3 f. Notably, the crystal phase of t-ZrO2 appears at the edge of m-ZrO2. The finding of mixed crystal phases conforms the result revealed by XRD analyses. For Ni/ZrO2-C catalyst, the neighboring lattice fringes of 0.240 and 0.287 nm correspond to the (111) and (111) planes of NiO and m-ZrO2, respectively. N2 sorption was employed to investigate specific surface area and pore structure of the serial catalysts. As shown in Fig. 4 a, all Ni/ZrO2 catalysts display the typical Ⅳ curves with H3 hysteresis loop, indicating the presence of mesoporous structure [22,23]. The pore size distributions are placed in Fig. 4 b, and the obvious mesoporous structure is confirmed. Besides, the surface area, pore diameter and pore volume of different catalysts are also presented in Table 1. Apparently, there exists a gradual decrease for Ni/ZrO2-A (12.93 m2/g), Ni/ZrO2-B (9.55 m2/g) and Ni/ZrO2-C (6.36 m2/g). The result is similar to the reported MOF-derived ZrO2 catalysts [31]. The corresponding pore volumes and sizes also follows this trend. The pore sizes of all samples are centered at the range of (23.8–26.7) nm, which are assigned as the stacking hole. Undoubtedly, the large pore size can accelerate the mass transfer and improve the catalytic activity. 3.2 Surface chemical state and redox property The surface compositions and chemical state of different catalysts were further determined by XPS spectra. As displayed in Fig. 5 A, the Zr 3d spectra are fitted into two peaks of Zr 3d3/2 (ca.184.2 eV) and Zr 3d5/2 (ca.181.8 eV) [32,33]. The binding energy of Zr 3d5/2 for Ni/ZrO2-B sample exhibit the highest value (181.88 eV), followed by Ni/ZrO2-A (181.81 eV) and Ni/ZrO2-C (181.69 eV). It was reported that the typical binding energy of Zr 3d5/2 (182.2 eV) was higher than that of our prepared samples [34]. This result should be ascribed to the partial reduction of surface Zr4+ species to Zr3+, being closely related with CH4 dissociation [35]. Thus, the Ni/ZrO2-C sample has the lowest binding energy compared with two other samples, improving the CH4 dissociation ability. For Ni/ZrO2-B sample, it has the highest binding energy of Zr, implying the strongest interaction between the surface Zr and O atoms [18]. The chemical states of oxygen species over different catalysts have been placed in Fig. 5 B. The O 1 s spectra were fitted into two peaks of surface lattice oxygen (Olatt) (ca. 530.1 eV) and surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads) (ca.531.5 eV) species [18,20], and the relative proportion of surface oxygen species were also placed in Table 2 . Clearly, the molar ratios (Oads/Olatt) of surface oxygen species show the following order of Ni/ZrO2-B (0.56)<Ni/ZrO2-A (0.96)<Ni/ZrO2-C (1.22). In general, the higher Oads/Olatt value means the more oxygen vacancies. It has been revealed that the oxygen vacancies could promote the CO2 activation [36,15], which facilitates the suppression of carbon deposition. Meanwhile, we note that the Ni/ZrO2-B sample has the largest amounts of surface lattice oxygen species, suggesting that the oxygen atoms have interacted strongly with Zr atoms. This result conforms to the analyses of Zr XPS spectra. Besides, the metal-support interaction between Ni and ZrO2 is also demonstrated by the high binding energy of the Ni2p3/2 peak centered at ca. 856 eV (Fig. S1). Compared with other two catalysts, the Ni2p3/2 peak of Ni/ZrO2-B shifts to a higher binding energy, indicating there exists the stronger interaction between Ni and ZrO2 support. The H2-TPR technique was employed to evaluate the interaction between Ni and ZrO2 support. As shown in Fig. 6 , the reduction temperatures over different catalysts are in the range from 300 to 600 °C. Two obvious reduction peaks are observed for all catalysts at the temperature of ca. 400 °C and 500 °C, respectively. The former reduction peak is ascribed to the reduction of highly dispersed NiO particles that had a weak interaction with the support, whereas the latter one is attributed to the reduction of embedded NiO particles in bulk ZrO2 matrix that had a strong interaction with the support [37,38]. Through the comparison of H2 consumption, we found that the Ni/ZrO2-B catalyst has the smallest amount of H2 consumption, and the higher reduction temperature. It suggests that the stronger interactions between Ni and ZrO2 appears in Ni/ZrO2-B catalyst [39], and the Ni–Zr–O solid solutions form in the case of high nickel contents. This finding is consistent with the XPS analyses. 3.3 Catalytic performance for DRM The catalytic performance of DRM for different Ni/ZrO2 catalysts has been evaluated. As shown in Fig. 7 , the performance of Ni/ZrO2-B catalyst is superior to that of Ni/ZrO2-A and Ni/ZrO2-C catalysts. Within the reaction time of 6 h, all catalysts exhibit a gradual decrease in varying degrees. In Fig. 7 A, a similar decrease of CH4 conversion from ca.76 % to ca.68 % appears over the Ni/ZrO2-A and Ni/ZrO2-B catalysts. The initial high activity should be attributed to the similar smaller Ni particles, which were determined by XRD and TEM characterizations. Because the Ni active sites were mainly responsible for CH4 dissociation [40], the similar activity toward CH4 conversion was observed on Ni/ZrO2-A and Ni/ZrO2-B catalysts. The Ni/ZrO2 C catalyst shows the lowest CH4 conversion, that decreases from ca.60 % to 45 % within 300 min. As such, the CO2 conversions over different catalysts also exhibit the same trend of decrease. The CO2 conversions over different catalysts follow the order of Ni/ZrO2-B>Ni/ZrO2-A>Ni/ZrO2-C. This phenomenon might be linked with the different ZrO2 phase, that affects the adsorption of CO2. It has been reported that (Zrδ+ and Zr4+ cations) species in t-ZrO2 phases generated the strong Lewis-type acid sites, being benefit for CO2 adsorption [41]. Together, the superior performance of Ni/ZrO2-B catalyst should be attributed to the strong metal-support interaction, as verified by XPS and TPR characterizations. Bitter et al. [42] reported that CH4 decomposition on the metal surface, and CO2 dissociation, and the adsorbed oxygen species through the formation of carbonate were closely related with the metal–support interface. This interaction can remain the Ni dispersion, enabling the catalyst with good stability. Of course, catalyst deactivation was also inevitably related to the decrease Ni dispersion and considerable coke accumulation [43]. Especially for Ni/ZrO2-C catalyst, the loss of activity decreased rapidly compared with other catalysts. The entailed discussion was placed behind based on the TG and XRD characterizations for spent catalysts. In addition, the generated H2/CO ratios over different catalysts are also displayed in Fig. 7 C. Clearly, the H2/CO ratios for all catalysts are below 1.0, implying the production of more CO molecules. This cause should be associated with the presence of side reaction of RWGS reaction, that CO2 reacts with yielding H2 to CO and H2O [44,45]. We also note that the H2/CO ratios in all catalysts follow the order of Ni/ZrO2-B (0.86)>Ni/ZrO2-A(0.81)>Ni/ZrO2-C (0.66) on the time of 150 min. This might be related with the surface properties of ZrO2 support, since they exhibit different crystallite phases. The low-strength OH groups in m-ZrO2 could be easily decomposed under high temperature, thus more oxygen anions or oxygen vacancies were formed [41]. As above characterizations (XRD and XPS) reveal that the Ni/ZrO2 C has the largest amount of m-ZrO2 phase and oxygen vacancies, following by Ni/ZrO2-A and Ni/ZrO2-B. And the more oxygen vacancies facilitate the adsorption of H2O, boosting the progress of unwanted RWGS reaction. Therefore, the Ni/ZrO2-C catalyst has the lowest H2/CO ratio. Meanwhile, considering the higher conversion of CO2 and higher H2/CO on Ni/ZrO2-B, it cannot be ruled out that carbon monoxide disproportionation reaction occurred, and CO could be converted to CO2. CO2 adsorption onto the reduced catalysts was studied by in-situ DRIFTS, aiming to identify the surface chemical properties related with CO2 activation. As shown in Fig. 8 , all the Ni/ZrO2 catalysts display three main bands at ca.1550, 1430 and 1320 cm−1 in the region of 1800–1200 cm−1. The bands at 1565 and 1342, 1320 cm−1 are ascribed to the bidentate carbonates species [46,47]. The band at 1430 cm−1 is ascribed to the bicarbonates species [46], and the band at 1442 cm−1 belongs to the CH3 species [17,48,49]. The bands at 1545 and 1370 cm−1 are ascribed to monodentate species [38], which are formed by CO2 adsorption onto the unsaturated oxygen vacancies. Notably, only mono-dentate carbonate species (1545 and 1370 cm−1) appear on the Ni/ZrO2-C catalyst. It indicates that the absence of Lewis acid sites is associated with the absence of polydentate carbonate species, agreeing well with above analyses. Besides, we also note that the intensities of these bands in the Ni/ZrO2-C sample are lower than those in the Ni/ZrO2-A and Ni/ZrO2-B samples, implying the weaker CO2 adsorption and activation. This capability might be attributed to the ZrO2 phase and amounts of Lewis acid sites [41]. In order to study the carbon deposition issue, the spent catalysts were further characterized by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). As shown in Fig. 9 A, different weight loss behavior has been observed in three spent Ni/ZrO2 catalysts. Clearly, all the weight losses occur at ca.610 °C, which should be attributed to the combustion of graphitic carbon [50,51]. The mass losses in three catalysts follow the order of Ni/ZrO2-A (6.9 %)>Ni/ZrO2-B(3.8 %)>Ni/ZrO2-C (0.7 %), indicating that the largest carbon deposition appears on the Ni/ZrO2-A catalyst. As referred above, the smaller Ni particles in Ni/ZrO2-A and Ni/ZrO2-B favor the CH4 decomposition and CO disproportionation, that easily forms carbon species. In addition, a strong acidity in catalysts always suffered from considerable carbon deposition [52]. The large amounts of carbon deposit on Ni/ZrO2-A and Ni/ZrO2-B are probably linked to the catalysts’ Lewis acid sites. It has been reported that (Zrδ+ and Zr4+ cations) species in t-ZrO2 phases generated the strong Lewis-type acid sites, being benefit for CO2 adsorption [41]. The absence of strong Lewis acid sites (cus Zr4+ sites) was confirmed by FTIR analysis, and also played an important role in suppressing coke formation because carbon is prone to formation on acid sites [53].Whereas the Ni/ZrO2-C catalyst has the largest oxygen vacancies, boosting the CO2 activation and the suppression of carbon deposition [15,36]. In Fig. 9 B, the XRD characterization for the spent catalysts has been measured. According to the Scherrer equation, the corresponding Ni particle sizes were calculated as 27.64, 16.60 and 33.18 nm for Ni/ZrO2-A, Ni/ZrO2-B, and Ni/ZrO2-C, respectively. Through comparison, it can be inferred that the severe sintering was occurred on Ni/ZrO2-A and Ni/ZrO2-C catalysts. The Ni particle size on Ni/ZrO2-B catalyst was slightly affected by reaction process. This result was well correlated with their catalytic performance, and the Ni/ZrO2-B catalyst showed the robust performance, whereas the Ni/ZrO2-C catalyst showed a rapid deactivation. Thus, the related deactivation should be ascribed to the sintering of Ni particle other than carbon deposit, especially for Ni/ZrO2-C catalyst. This also provide an effective strategy for catalyst design for DRM reaction. 4 Conclusions The embedded Ni@ZrO2 catalysts were controllable synthesized by sacrificial Zr-MOFs template strategy, which were applied to methane reforming with carbon dioxide (DRM), and a clear structure-activity relationship was established. The relevant physicochemical properties of all samples were characterized by many characterization techniques. The XRD results revealed that all ZrO2 matrix possessed mixed crystalline phase (monoclinic and tetragonal ZrO2), that had an effect on surface oxygen vacancies and acid sites. It revealed that small Ni particles benefited CH4 activation, the acid sites boosted CO2 activation, and the oxygen vacancies could reduce carbon deposition. Amongst, the Ni/ZrO2-B catalyst shows the best performance toward CH4 and CO2 conversion, H2/CO ratio, and stability, following by Ni/ZrO2-A and Ni/ZrO2-C catalysts. The superior catalytic performance of Ni/ZrO2-B should be attributed to highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles and strong metal-support interaction (SMSI). This interaction can remain the Ni dispersion, enabling the catalyst with good stability. coredata.dc:description: Metal-support interaction (MSI) plays an important role in heterogeneous catalysis, that could be well regulated by many strategies. Here, Ni@ZrO2 catalysts were controllably synthesized by sacrificial Zr-MOFs template strategy, and were applied to the dry reforming of methane (DRM). Amongst, the Ni/ZrO2-B catalyst shows the best performance toward CH4 and CO2 conversion, H2/CO ratio, and stability, following by Ni/ZrO2-A and Ni/ZrO2 C catalysts. The difference in catalytic performance should be ascribed to different synthetic strategy, resulting in different properties of Ni species and ZrO2 matrix, and interface interaction. It revealed that small Ni particles were benefit for CH4 activation, and strong MSI boosted CO2 activation, that could remain the Ni dispersion and thermal stability. This study is beneficial to the catalyst design in DRM reaction.
coredata.dc:title: MOFs-derived Ni@ZrO2 catalyst for dry reforming of methane: Tunable metal-support interaction
